raw_answer: PCR direct sequencing, high-resolution melting (HRM) analysis, Haplotype analysis
question: Format answer for: Regarding patient 'D': What genetic methods were used in this study?
context:
Based on the information contained within the provided document, the following genetic methods were used in this study regarding patient 'D':

Patient 'D' was identified as a patient with sporadic PD (SPD) who had the p.D620N mutation in the VPS35 gene. The genetic methods applied to Patient 'D' (as an SPD patient and as a carrier of the p.D620N mutation) according to the "Genetic Analysis" section (page 2) include:

1.  **Genomic DNA extraction**: "Genomic DNA was extracted from peripheral blood using a standard protocol."
2.  **PCR direct sequencing**: Patient D, as an SPD patient, was "examined for the following 7 variants: p.M571 (exon 3), p.1241M (exon 7), p.P316S (exon 9), p.R524W (exon 13), p.D620N (exon 15), p.A737V (exon 16), and p.L774M (exon 17) of VPS35... PCR direct sequencing was performed using a BigDye Terminator v1.1 Cycle Sequencing kit and 3130 Genetic Analyzer (Applied Biosystems, Foster City, CA) or 3730 DNA Analyzer (Applied Biosystems)."
3.  **High-resolution melting (HRM) analysis**: As an SPD patient, Patient D was "also genotyped for c.1858G>A (p.D620N) mutation by high-resolution melting (HRM) analysis using LightScanner and LCGreen plus (Idaho Technology, Salt Lake City, UT)."
4.  **Analysis of all exons of VPS35**: Since Patient D was found to carry the p.D620N mutation, "All exons of VPS35 were also analyzed in patients with the p.D620N mutation using the method described previously.Â³" The results confirmed that "Patients carrying the p.D620N mutation did not have any other variants in all exons of VPS35." (page 3).
5.  **Haplotype analysis**: "Haplotype analysis of the VPS35 flanking region was performed using 3130 Genetic analyzer and GeneMapper software (Applied Biosystems, Foster City, CA)." Table 1 on page 3 explicitly includes data for patient 'D' under "Haplotype analysis of VPS35 p.D620N mutation carriers."
